üõ† is an important action. üõ†üõ£ is more economy-efficient as it increases economy by 2 while a new üè≠ increases economy by 1. It's important to have a plan on where to üõ† (
) to maximise üõ£ while meeting other economic objectives.
Playing a card for the event is often worse than using it for üõ†. It's important to have some kind of exchange rate between different effects and regular üõ†. For example, although the
has a strong effect, the 4üõ† are often more valuable in D1.

Adding üòÅ is more efficiently done with 1-value cards, as the shortfall that it bridges could usually be replaced by a üõ†, which is permanent, which contributes to economy/export factory value and also can be dismantled for future ‚ùåüò° actions.
‚ùåüò° actions can be important to ‚ùåüëø, and they can be important for East in D4. In other cases, they is not efficient.

properties.ariaLabel: Playing cards from the board permalink

children.value: In each half-decade, 7 cards are laid out on the board. Each card is often worth a different value to each player. For example,

is worth at least 4üõ† to West and at least 1üõ† to East. We can say that the swing value is at least 5üõ†. Naively, we can say that we can extract most relative value from the board cards by taking the cards with the highest swing value. However, the values of cards in WSDV are often dynamic depending on board state, tracks, üñêüÉè and other cards on the board. Nevertheless, it's useful to think about the swing value of cards.

It is generally best to play üñêüÉè when 1 card is left on the board in the first half of each decade (D1.5, D2.5, ...). In every other situation, the opponent gets to take an extra card from the board, which results in them either getting better picks of the cards or them getting to play more cards than us.

In the usual case, at the end of each first-half-decade, P1 has the power to choose how many üñêüÉè to play and P2 must either follow suit or give up the first pick of the second-half-decade, which is the card with the highest swing value. As there are some particularly strong cards in each decade, this is a great advantage of being P1.

P1 should play their strong üñêüÉè at the end of each first-half-decade. A large advantage can be gained if they have strong üñêüÉè and P2 is forced to play weak üñêüÉè. If P1 has weak üñêüÉè, they can

the decade by playing no üñêüÉè and P2 will need to give up some board cards to play his üñêüÉè. P1 should generally not play weak üñêüÉè, since it gives P2 an easy opportunity to play a strong üñêüÉè if they have one (or the build the wall in D2).

There are two exceptions to playing strong üñêüÉè at the ends of the first-half-decades. The first is having ‚ùåüò° in hand as West in D2 and the board having no üëø. It is good to save the ‚ùåüò° until after East plays üò° cards in D2.5. The second exception is having
as East. These are often useful to save for late in the decade to play, where the opponent often cannot repair the damage done from ‚ùåüõ† before the decade ends.
‚≠êÔ∏è is of high importance overall, but parts of the ‚≠êÔ∏è track differ in

(urgency of contesting the track). The middle of the track, between -1‚≠êÔ∏è and +1‚≠êÔ∏è is the hottest. Between -1‚≠êÔ∏è and -4‚≠êÔ∏è is the coolest part of the track, as there is relatively little difference between 1üîΩüè≠ and 1‚ùåüõ† + 1üò°.

Becoming P1 is an important reward of ‚≠êÔ∏è. P1 decides how many üñêüÉè can be conveniently played in the decade and P1 gets increased value from odd numbers of flight ‚ùåüõ† and üîΩüè≠ from WC shortage.
Gaining 1üõ† as East is also a great reward. It often allows East to negate the effects of flight ‚ùåüõ† hurting East's export factories (which cause WC shortage and üîΩüè≠).

1‚ùåüò° as East is comparable to gaining 1üõ†. It's sometimes worse. The +3‚≠ê bonus is strong, with both 1 üõ† and 1 ‚ùåüò°. It's often stronger than the +4‚≠êÔ∏è bonus of üòÅ. The üòÅ needs to be maintained by economy and paid for by WC, and is generally only good in D4 when survival is all that matters.
Going past +6‚≠êÔ∏è as East is a rare occurrence, but is powerful when üò° is already a problem for West.

Gaining 1üîΩüè≠ as West is a similarly powerful reward. üè≠ which haven't been run down are important resources to skilled East players, because they prevent WC shortage in D4 from dismantling infrastructure. The 1üîΩüè≠ can often cause a WC shortage especially in D1, which is worth another 1üîΩüè≠.

LS removal at -5‚≠êÔ∏è and -6‚≠êÔ∏è is generally very strong, once West's border provinces have at least 2üòÅ on them. What commonly happens is that 1‚ùåüòÅ leads to 2 to 3 extra üò° hits, 2 from the neighbouring West provinces and 1 from internal üòÅ comparison if any East provinces have 2üòÅ already. This means that -5‚≠êÔ∏è and -6‚≠êÔ∏è can cause a total of 3-4üò°, which can be a killing blow to an otherwise solid East side in D4.

children.value: Between the üõ† and üòÅ actions, üòÅ actions should be left to as late in the decade as possible, since üòÅ doesn't help at all during the decade, whereas üõ† helps create economy for üòÅ.

properties.ariaLabel: Where to build and LS West  permalink

children.value: Where to üõ† üè≠ and üõ£ is of crucial importance. An efficient plan of üõ† generates more economy and reaches minimum export of 2 and 3 earlier than an inefficient plan.

children.value: With 6üõ†, West can achieve this first milestone. West can now place 1üòÅ in Nieder, Hessen and WB (from NordWest) with a 1-value card. The hanging connection from M√ºnchen allows us to üòÅ there with a 1-value card in case East places üëø in Bayern via
. The üòÅ there allows 1‚ùåüò° and protects Bayern from further üòÅ attack, which would otherwise often be critical damage.

children.value: With 11üõ†, West can achieve this next milestone. Here, West has a minimum export level of 2 and can make 1üòÅ in WB and each border province, as well as either RheinPfalz or Baden to prepare for the 2nd üòÅ to WB.

In this configuration, it's ideal if West can supply the first üòÅ to WB from Baden (then the 2nd üòÅ from RheinPfalz and 3rd from NordWest) instead of from NordWest as set up in the first milestone. This is for two reasons. First, Baden is the only WB supplier which can have an export level of 3 with only one üè≠, that makes Baden most efficient as the first supplier, since the first supplier only needs 2-3 economy. Any extra üõ† should be allocated to other provinces. Second, NordWest is the set target of the

in D3. By having it as the third supplier to WB, it will naturally be the most built up and unrest is naturally removed from it by the first two üòÅ added to it. This acts as a convenient defense towards the otherwise potentially troublesome
However, it's no big loss if NordWest is the first WB supplier.

children.value: With 20 build, West can get a very strong position as shown here. This build assumes that the first supplier to WB was Baden. The second supplier here is RheinPfalz. The position has a minimum export level of 3 and can develop 2üòÅ in all border provinces and WB. With just two more üõ† in NordWest, West can have 8 economy there and deliver the 3rd üòÅ to WB. Such a position, together with the events in D4, is often enough to craft the West üò° victory in D4.

West should prefer to LS in at least one Hamburg province (Nieder or Schleswig) for each LS action. An easy mistake to make is to forget that Hamburg cannot count for both provinces, and thus be unable to LS in both Nieder and Schleswig in the same action.

properties.ariaLabel: Managing unrest and mass protests  permalink

children.value: üò° is a large threat for several reasons. Firstly, because 4üëø at decade end leads to game loss. Importantly, when both East and West have 4üëø at decade end, West loses. Secondly, because üëø in a province with 0, 1 or 2 export level will limit West's minimum export level, reducing West's pressure on East's WC. Thirdly, because üëø in WB in particular means that WB's offensive power (vs Brandenburg and East Berlin) will be reduced, WB's üòÅ will limit the border provinces' üòÅ or it will suffer from internal üòÅ comparison, and further üòÅ of WB will be hindered because of the exported üëø.

A particularly nasty scenario with üò° is having a province with üëø dismantled to zero economy so that it cannot support any üòÅ. That opens the province up to extra üò° from neighbours and internal comparison, putting the province even further from rescue.
and prioritising üõ† is a great defense vs üò°, since it allows the natural development of üòÅ to ‚ùåüò°, which also advances the game plan of attacking East through external üòÅ comparison.
It is important to be familiar with East's üò° cards, as well as West's ‚ùåüò° cards.
Monetary Reform in the West (1‚ùåüò° excl WB)
should usually ‚ùåüò° evenly between Bayern and Hessen.

is a very important card which has 2‚ùåüò° for WB. Although WB is not under immediate threat in D1, this is a defense in preparation for D2 and D3, where WB can come under heavy fire, with devastating consequence. It's crucial to not let Bayern have üëø and no üòÅ at the end of D1, or the situation will only get worse in D2. One good defense against this is to üõ†üè≠ in Munchen(in Bayern) and hang an üõ£ to Stuttgart(in Baden) as soon as possible, so that West can build at Stuttgart and bring Bayern to 2 economy, so that üòÅ can be efficiently placed to defend Bayern and give 1‚ùåüò°.
In D2, there are three key cards for ‚ùåüò°.
Short term Berlin visas (2‚ùåüò° in WB)
Ish bin ein Bearleener (3‚ùåüò°, of which 1 in WB)
Take a chance on more democracy (2‚ùåüò°)
.  The Berlin visas can be important especially if East gets
in D1. Prioriting üõ† in Bayern can help its defense.
is the only powerful card for dealing with unrest. The

is somewhat better than taking the ‚ùåüò° action. By this time, the ideal situation is that your economy and üòÅ provide the natural solution to üò°, but it is also reasonable to use the ‚ùåüò° action to remove üëø from WB.
are mostly there to quell any üëø from some of the üò° cards in the decade, in order to get maximum hits onto East through external üòÅ comparison.

When deciding when to ‚ùåüò° to clear üëø, it's also important to recognise when to simply ignore the üëø and focus on üõ† and üòÅ in other provinces instead. üëø in the non-border provinces is often inconsequential once the province has been sufficiently built up. üëø in Bayern should also sometimes be ignored if it is not anticipated to accumulate to 4üëø by end of D4.
Going into D4, having at least one East province be in üëø confers a strong advantage to West. West can follow up the üëø in D4 with either
which each give 2‚ùåüõ†, which can often bring a province down to 0 economy and make it unable to maintain üòÅ.
Beyond this combination of üëø and ‚ùåüõ†, it's important to place as much üò° on East as possible to cause 4üëø for the East, which often includes prioritising cards like
. It's a good practice to consciously map out where the 4üëø will come from, and work backwards from there when placing üò°.

children.value: The best target provinces for üò° cards are Bayern, WB and Hessen. On the flip side, Bayern is an very important province to keep at 0 or 1 üò°, not just as defense against üò°, but also to accomodate the
